p:
Many of the state-of-the-art forecast systems developed for respiratory pathogens such as influenza use ensemble predictions generated with a mathematical model of disease transmission, such as an SIR model, that has been optimized using Bayesian inference methods [ 27, 33, 35, 37â€“ 39]. These inference methods enable estimation of model state variables (e.g. number of susceptible and infected) and critical epidemiological parameters (e.g. R
0 ). Here we paired an SIR model with the EAKF to predict RSV incidence. We have shown that the model-filter forecasts are generally more accurate than historical expectance ( Fig 5), and that forecast accuracy can be distinguished using ensemble variance ( Fig 4). This latter finding enables distinction of forecast reliability in real time.
